summary: Talking to your babies may boost their IQ, study suggests
title: Talking to your babies may boost their IQ, study suggests
body:
A new study in the journal Pediatrics has found that talking to your toddler can enhance their development, including boosting IQ, verbal comprehension and vocabulary.

Read more from CTV Health News https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/talking-to-your-babies-may-boost-their-iq-study-suggests-1.4090326

blog.name: fitnessgrace
blog.title: Fitness+Health+Grace
blog.description: Wellness is not about getting skinny, putting on a show about how you have the perfect balance or proving how hard you're trying. It's about understanding why your body is responding the way it is to the stimulous around you, learning what it needs to be healthy, doing the actual work YOU need to do and knowing that you're enough during the process of getting to where you want to be.

summary: The pain was the same or maybe more than the last time. So was my scream when that big oaf came straight down on my foot during...
body:
Injuries & The Memory of Past Injuries



The pain was the same or maybe more than the last time. So was my scream when that big oaf came straight down on my foot during my co-ed soccer game (we’re really all probably too old to still be doing this, but love of the game).


And it all came rushing back. This hurts like that hurt. I just screamed, like I screamed. I can’t put weight on it without a crazy rush of knock me out pain. BREATHE.


Just another night in my Monday night soccer league landing me in the urgent care to get X-rays the next day.


And then, the relieving news: it’s just a really bad contusion. No broken bones. 7-10 days in a boot and you should be healing up quick.


NO BROKEN BONES.


I swear it was like someone told me I won the lottery or something, “you mean the next two years of my life won’t be devoted to this injury?”


And today, other than the fact I’m wearing a boot, need to ice and rest up—normal life. Normal work day. Normal 50+ messages from my soccer team talking about the USA vs Mexico game last night (that I missed, sadly). A normal morning routine.


I’m hit with the reality: this really isn’t last time.


I really have been carrying the fear of last time with me for a few years now. I know it’s called Post Traumatic Stress Dysregulation (have they officially changed it from disorder yet?) and I have been being treated for it in relation to various traumas before. But it’s like I wasn’t aware this was still a thing for me.


The last time I had an injury of similar occurance in a soccer game, I broke my leg badly. I was non-weight bearing for 2 straight months, I was in a boot for another 2 months. I couldn’t walk regularly for about 2 months. It didn’t heal for 6 months. And I basically couldn’t be normal in my workouts again for 2 years between my muscle imbalances, weight gain and new injuries from my missing strength.


All I could think was: ITS HAPPENING AGAIN. I DON’T KNOW IF I HAVE THIS IN ME, AGAIN.


It took a good friend sitting with me through part of the night to help calm me down. I knew I was panicking, but in moment where you are panicking or retriggered, calming down isn’t a matter of just saying ‘CALM DOWN.’ There is rush of chemicals racing through your body to deal with to. There are physical and emotional elements to manage.


My friend helped me realized that so much of my fear about this being broken was my work situation and fear I wouldn’t be able to teach a full load of students, and what might the parents of my students think of me, and what might it do to my income. She reminded me, that I’ve always been provided for, EVEN when I actually did break my leg….really badly.


And then there were the thoughts like, “wow soccer is so dangerous, how is it that I keep forgetting that. I’m so lucky I didn’t get another concussion or tear of something! Why am I even playing!? Maybe I shouldn’t be playing, but I love to play?! What if I stop playing and I get fat again?! What if I keep playing and get injured again?! Shut up Erin! You don’t even know if it’s broke.”


Welcome to the mind of panic, I’m sure you’ve been there in one way or another.


I think the message today is: we are not our pasts. These past injuries (on many levels) do no get to layer up on new injuries and reak fear havoc within us. And we have to find it within ourselves to see with fresh eyes when this is happening, and say NO. THIS IS NOT THEN. This is now, the situation is different.


My injury is not the same as my inury 3.5 years ago. It is a totally different injury requiring a totally different wellness plan. I get to give myself a little grace to rest a little more this week to heal up well—-but I don’t actually have to take any real time off from working out to heal. I have to simply do workouts within my currently scope (not on my feet, there are plenty of workouts to do).


There is a lot of Core work I’ve been neglecting, I can do some yoga (I have a yoga harness to even help!), I can do arm strengthening with free weights, work on my hip strengtheners. This actually doesn’t need or get to be a week off. I need to take care, yes, but this is a moment where it’s important for me to stay as normal to my life routine as possible to break the hold that fear from a previous injury wants to edge. Nope. Not today.


I’m writing this post hoping to encourage you to look at those past inuries (or sicknesses and traumas) and ask yourself if those are still secretly driving how you workout and really how you live? It’s not to say be dumb, I mean, use the lessons of the past—-but I’m curious if more of us than we think are bringing these past traumas with us into our present days, and letting it impact our results?


It’s time to let go. It’s a new day. You have strength for it. So do I.

blog.name: fitworlds
blog.title: Health & Fitness FANatic
blog.description: Fitness and Health Tips for Women Who Hate Diets

summary: Is there a greater risk of illness when working out too hard? via /r/Fitness
title: Is there a greater risk of illness when working out too hard? via /r/Fitness
body:
Basically title.

I’ve been working out off and on for about 5+ years now and the biggest thing that holds me back is getting sick.

I’ll say it’s been more apparent recently as I’ve finally gotten into doing actual routines. One routine in particular I’ve been doing is the Nsuns routine. It’s easy to track with the free app and gets me to make strength gains on a consistent basis. If I’m healthy that is…

And that’s my problem. I can’t stay healthy for more than a month or two at a time. I work in a school environment and am constantly exposed to children, so I do extra things to make sure I remain healthy (wash my hands plenty, make sure to rest, take daily vitamins, etc…) but it seems it’s never enough.

I’m writing this in my hospital bed as I’ve got pneumonia in my right lung and I’m fed up with being sick all the damn time.

Do I need to be on a 3 day routine? Should I be doing something different? I do make sure to take a “rest” week every 3-4 weeks or so to do very light workouts and let my body have extra time to recover.

TL;DR - is a 5 day routine too much for me? Am I wearing down my immune system too much? I’m a 24 year old, healthy male and no matter how much I try I just can’t seem to avoid illness once I start to see some gains :/



Submitted September 12, 2018 at 02:09AM by jdb050
via reddit https://ift.tt/2x39yBK

And that’s my problem. I can’t stay healthy for more than a month or two at a time. I work in a school environment and am constantly exposed to children, so I do extra things to make sure I remain healthy (wash my hands plenty, make sure to rest, take daily vitamins, etc…) but it seems it’s never enough.

I’m writing this in my hospital bed as I’ve got pneumonia in my right lung and I’m fed up with being sick all the damn time.

Do I need to be on a 3 day routine? Should I be doing something different? I do make sure to take a “rest” week every 3-4 weeks or so to do very light workouts and let my body have extra time to recover.

TL;DR - is a 5 day routine too much for me? Am I wearing down my immune system too much? I’m a 24 year old, healthy male and no matter how much I try I just can’t seem to avoid illness once I start to see some gains :/



Submitted September 12, 2018 at 02:09AM by jdb050
via reddit https://ift.tt/2x39yBK

summary: Ohio State Football: 5 Things Learned About the Buckeyes After Two Games https://ift.tt/eA8V8J
title: Ohio State Football: 5 Things Learned About the Buckeyes After Two Games https://ift.tt/eA8V8J
description:
Two games into the 2018 season, the Ohio State Buckeyes are 2-0, scoring 129 points, allowing 34, for an average score of 64-17. The fact that Ohio State easily handled their first two opponents was not altogether surprising. The fact that Ohio State has been so impressive while dealing with the game day absence of head coach Urban Meyer should be encouraging.

summary: (7/16) -“…Music is a very powerful auditory stimulus and can be used to assuage negative bodily sensations that usually arise...
caption:
(7/16) -“…Music is a very powerful auditory stimulus and can be used to assuage negative bodily sensations that usually arise during exercise-related situations. This psychophysical response is triggered by an attentional mechanism that will ultimately result in a more efficacious control of the musculature,” Bigliassi told PsyPost…„-
🇷🇺 -“…Музыка - очень мощный слуховой стимул и может использоваться для успокоения негативных телесных ощущений, которые обычно возникают во время ситуаций, связанных с физической нагрузкой. Этот психофизический ответ вызван механизмом внимания, который в конечном итоге приведет к более эффективному контролю над мускулатурой », - сказал Бильясси PsyPost…„

blog.description:
My name is Boby Jarrar, a Registered Nutritionist. I have been interested in healthy lifestyle especially in healthy eating. We’re all living in a changing world and the way we live have changed drastically. Our jobs mostly are getting more and more sedentary and our foods were mostly processed with too much sugar, sodium, bad cholesterol, saturated fats and oil. It’s okay to eat anything but in moderation.

Check out our website

blog.name: entirebodyexercise
blog.title: Entire Body Exercise
blog.description: A Fitness Consultant, empowering people to live a healthy and long life. I bring you some great tips on health, fitness, diet and more.

summary: Eating This Way Can Improve Heart Health
title: Eating This Way Can Improve Heart Health
body:
Scientific evidence continuouslies install that mindfulness is a fount of health and wellness as well as well-being. Current research locates that mindfulness meditation-a relaxation exercise of sitting still, bringing focus to the breath and also discovering passing ideas without judgment-can minimize physical and also psychological pain, ease signs and symptoms of migraine headaches and help calm aggressiveness in kids.

But even when you’re not sitting in meditation, living mindfully could have actual health and wellness effects, suggests a brand-new research study released in the journal Obesity. The researchers located that finding out the best ways to eat mindfully was connected to much better procedures of heart health.

The scientists placed 194 overweight individuals on a five-month diet and also workout program, which was geared towards weight-loss. Additionally, some were provided training in mindfulness, which took location during a 2.5-hour classes held regarding each week. In addition to reflection and also yoga, this group obtained mindful eating skills, like discovering how to identify the body’s hunger and also fullness hints as well as differentiating physical desires for food from psychological ones. ‘Often it’s tough to inform the difference between being stressed as well as starving,’ claims Jennifer Daubenmier, assistant lecturer at the Osher Establishment for Integrative Medication at the College of The golden state, San Francisco, who led the research. The mindfulness team in some cases ate dishes during course as a workout, stopping every so typically to evaluate exactly how hungry or full they were.

Another exercise was to consume a raisin making use of all of the body’s senses: looking at it, holding it, scenting it, sampling it, eating it. 'It’s not our normal eating actions, which typically could be really automated,’ claims Daubenmier. Vital, too, was helping people be kinder to as well as a lot more approving of themselves. 'Many individuals that are overweight feeling pity or guilt if they do eat way too much,’ Daubenmier claims. 'We acknowledge that becomes part of the process and also it’s a chance to find out about one’s patterns, not to blame oneself.’

To make up for all this added knowing time, the scientists offered the control group additional details on nutrition as well as exercise.

After the program, the researchers waited a year. 'Prior study has shown that cautious eating programs could boost eating behaviors, yet we do not really find out about the longer term effect after the program finishes,’ says Daubenmier. 'When individuals are left by themselves, do they merely resume their very own behaviors?’

The results recommend that several persevere. Individuals in the mindfulness team shed approximately 3.7 pounds much more compared to individuals in the control team. That effect wasn’t statistically considerably different from those in the control group. When they looked at specific danger elements for type-2 diabetic issues as well as heart disease-including fasting sugar degrees a year after the program ended and also triglyceride degrees a year after the program began-they did find a significant distinction. Those improvements were likely due to reduced tension, weight-loss or better food options, the writers hypothesize. 'We really felt that perhaps this mindfulness program was stopping a boosted risk of diabetic issues,’ Daubenmier says.

Intriguing as the finding is, more study in bigger teams of people is needed. As well as while contemplating your next dish could not be the key to significant effective weight loss, there’s first proof that it could undoubtedly have some genuine benefits.

Additionally, some were provided training in mindfulness, which took location during a 2.5-hour classes held regarding each week. In addition to reflection and also yoga, this group obtained mindful eating skills, like discovering how to identify the body’s hunger and also fullness hints as well as differentiating physical desires for food from psychological ones. ‘Often it’s tough to inform the difference between being stressed as well as starving,’ claims Jennifer Daubenmier, assistant lecturer at the Osher Establishment for Integrative Medication at the College of The golden state, San Francisco, who led the research. The mindfulness team in some cases ate dishes during course as a workout, stopping every so typically to evaluate exactly how hungry or full they were.

Another exercise was to consume a raisin making use of all of the body’s senses: looking at it, holding it, scenting it, sampling it, eating it. 'It’s not our normal eating actions, which typically could be really automated,’ claims Daubenmier. Vital, too, was helping people be kinder to as well as a lot more approving of themselves. 'Many individuals that are overweight feeling pity or guilt if they do eat way too much,’ Daubenmier claims. 'We acknowledge that becomes part of the process and also it’s a chance to find out about one’s patterns, not to blame oneself.’

To make up for all this added knowing time, the scientists offered the control group additional details on nutrition as well as exercise.

After the program, the researchers waited a year. 'Prior study has shown that cautious eating programs could boost eating behaviors, yet we do not really find out about the longer term effect after the program finishes,’ says Daubenmier. 'When individuals are left by themselves, do they merely resume their very own behaviors?’

The results recommend that several persevere. Individuals in the mindfulness team shed approximately 3.7 pounds much more compared to individuals in the control team. That effect wasn’t statistically considerably different from those in the control group. When they looked at specific danger elements for type-2 diabetic issues as well as heart disease-including fasting sugar degrees a year after the program ended and also triglyceride degrees a year after the program began-they did find a significant distinction. Those improvements were likely due to reduced tension, weight-loss or better food options, the writers hypothesize. 'We really felt that perhaps this mindfulness program was stopping a boosted risk of diabetic issues,’ Daubenmier says.

Intriguing as the finding is, more study in bigger teams of people is needed. As well as while contemplating your next dish could not be the key to significant effective weight loss, there’s first proof that it could undoubtedly have some genuine benefits.
trail.content:
External image

Scientific evidence continuouslies install that mindfulness is a fount of health and wellness as well as well-being. Current research locates that mindfulness meditation-a relaxation exercise of sitting still, bringing focus to the breath and also discovering passing ideas without judgment-can minimize physical and also psychological pain, ease signs and symptoms of migraine headaches and help calm aggressiveness in kids.

But even when you’re not sitting in meditation, living mindfully could have actual health and wellness effects, suggests a brand-new research study released in the journal Obesity. The researchers located that finding out the best ways to eat mindfully was connected to much better procedures of heart health.

The scientists placed 194 overweight individuals on a five-month diet and also workout program, which was geared towards weight-loss. Additionally, some were provided training in mindfulness, which took location during a 2.5-hour classes held regarding each week. In addition to reflection and also yoga, this group obtained mindful eating skills, like discovering how to identify the body’s hunger and also fullness hints as well as differentiating physical desires for food from psychological ones. ‘Often it’s tough to inform the difference between being stressed as well as starving,’ claims Jennifer Daubenmier, assistant lecturer at the Osher Establishment for Integrative Medication at the College of The golden state, San Francisco, who led the research. The mindfulness team in some cases ate dishes during course as a workout, stopping every so typically to evaluate exactly how hungry or full they were.

Another exercise was to consume a raisin making use of all of the body’s senses: looking at it, holding it, scenting it, sampling it, eating it. 'It’s not our normal eating actions, which typically could be really automated,’ claims Daubenmier. Vital, too, was helping people be kinder to as well as a lot more approving of themselves. 'Many individuals that are overweight feeling pity or guilt if they do eat way too much,’ Daubenmier claims. 'We acknowledge that becomes part of the process and also it’s a chance to find out about one’s patterns, not to blame oneself.’

To make up for all this added knowing time, the scientists offered the control group additional details on nutrition as well as exercise.

After the program, the researchers waited a year. 'Prior study has shown that cautious eating programs could boost eating behaviors, yet we do not really find out about the longer term effect after the program finishes,’ says Daubenmier. 'When individuals are left by themselves, do they merely resume their very own behaviors?’

The results recommend that several persevere. Individuals in the mindfulness team shed approximately 3.7 pounds much more compared to individuals in the control team. That effect wasn’t statistically considerably different from those in the control group. When they looked at specific danger elements for type-2 diabetic issues as well as heart disease-including fasting sugar degrees a year after the program ended and also triglyceride degrees a year after the program began-they did find a significant distinction. Those improvements were likely due to reduced tension, weight-loss or better food options, the writers hypothesize. 'We really felt that perhaps this mindfulness program was stopping a boosted risk of diabetic issues,’ Daubenmier says.

Intriguing as the finding is, more study in bigger teams of people is needed. As well as while contemplating your next dish could not be the key to significant effective weight loss, there’s first proof that it could undoubtedly have some genuine benefits.
